All the whining about Apple and Adobe is pointless. Apple invented and controls the devices and the App store and who sells Apps on it. It's not a public place anymore than Walmart. If Walmart does not have what you want, go to Kmart or Saxs or other stores.
So if Apple wants to control, for any reason, any part of this private closed system, they can.
Me, I like it. Unlike Microsoft, Apple tends to get it right when they control it.
Awesome. My favourite Twitter app for the Mac.

Given that I am paying to download to my phone, and that here, at the edge of the known universe, those speeds can make dialup look fast, I am really really looking forward to wasting my quota on iphone ads.

In fact, I am breathless with anticipation.

I am counting the nanoseconds until this tremendous innovation reaches us.

How many sleeps? How will I live until that grand day arrives?

Apps which push ads, first to buy themselves (OK, fair) and then go on to demand I buy other stuff, get deleted. Fast.
Still waiting to see a coherent strategy for Microsoft other than "look they have one, let's build one too." Titanic going around in circles.

I love my Ipad.  It has actually made me read more books and I really love the bookmarking feature.  I really didn't want to expect too much as I use my iPhone to read sites in the morning. Now I have a bigger space and just overall happy with this technology.  Maybe it's not for everyone and that's okay.

I don't get it, I pay for the phone, I pay for the service, I pay for the app. Yet I have not paid enough and now have to watch ads?  Give me a break.  I think this would be the straw that breaks the camels back, I'll walk away the service sucks on teh phone anyway.

I guess Tweetie wasn't doing all that well. Especially since it will now fall into the "free app" category. I always thought it was a nice app that came out at the right time. Tweetie 2 was an attempt to keep riding the wave that crested on the original Tweetie (version 1), but alas many new Twitter apps have since proven to offer a much more pleasant user interface and better overall user experience.

Congrats to Loren for landing a job at Twitter on their Mobile Development team.

The three credit reporting agencies have devised a system that inherently lowers your credit score.  All credit checks lowers one's score.  The simple act of closing a credit card or other line of credit lowers one's score, regardless of how well one manages their accounts.  The credit reporting agencies accuracy and thoroughness is abhorrent.  Three times in the last year false information was placed on my report.  It took several months to correct, and guess what . . . my score did NOT increase to the value it was before the false information was placed on my report.  If the credit agencies want to market credit reports as a tool for human resource departments, then their methods of computing scores, verifying accuracy of information, and performing due diligence need serious improvement.  If employers want to check the credit reports of applicants, then they should also be held accountable for protecting the privacy and confidentiality of such information.

Isn't the Chairman of the Board of Transunion a member of the President's Economic Recovery Advisory Board which formulates and evaluates economic policy for the Obama Administration?

Wasn't the Chairman of the Board of Transunion also National Finance Chair of the Barack Obama for President campaign and co-chair of the 2009 Presidential Inaugural Committee?

Businesses running credit checks on potential employees is merely a symptom of the bad economy. Look at Michael Vick. He's had some very serious credit issues. Did he have any trouble finding a job once he got out of prison? That's because the economy looks pretty good if you're an NFL owner.

In the real world, the fact that you're an American filling out a job application tells the boss you're a potential risk, liability, and expense to be minimized. Thus, the credit check.

With the digital medical records that Obama is requiring with Obamacare , soon employers will require to see those too ( as well as them being sold for three bucks to anyone with an internet connection).  Nothing from social security numbers to now have ever just been used for what they were intended.

Maybe people with bad credit would be better to hire. If someone has a tenuous financial situation, their job might mean more to them and they may be less willing to quit. Maybe they would be more willing to put up with a less than ideal job if they have debts, for example.

Human Resource Departments and the people who work in them are nothing but brown-nose gophers for upper management. Have any of them ever worked at a real job in industry or with the companies that hired them. They go to college or a 'business' school and get a certificate or degree in Human Management.
The real people who should do the hiring are the managers and department heads who need good, trust-worthy, valuable people. And they in turn can actually tell the job applicant what the job or position is all about and what THEY are looking for.

Credit checks is just another invasion of a job applicants privacy and in no way tells what kind of worker a person will be. Good follow-up on what they state on their resumes, references, and past companies.
Companies are not allowed to ask an applicant how old they are -- so why are they allowed to use personal credit information. And like the article states, credit scores can be affected by person tragedy, illness & medical bills,lay-offs,divorce, etc. -- Next will be reviewing medical records.....and so on !!

If there's nothing wrong with bad credit why are some you posters encouraging legislation to help people hide their bad credit ? You know deep down that not handling money / credit responsibly often indicates poor judgement. This does provide a more complete piture for potential employers.

All other things being equal,the prospective hire with the better credit SHOULD get the edge. I don't think it's out-of-bounds to assume that many people who can't handle their personal finances responsibly will have problems handling other areas of their lives responsibly. If your credit is down as the result of a personal crisis outside your control, then explain that in the interview.

It those like this poster who simply do not get it that inability to live on slave wages and pay the basic bills has nothing to do with a work ethic or honesty when he writes:
#5 mark A displayed inability to manage one's finances and/or revealing financial irresponsibility is most definitely a key factor in determining suitability for employment. Only a fool would think otherwise.

Actually it usually says a LOT more about their employers who think people can actually live on $8 or 10 or 12 an hour and STILL make all payments on time for the rent, utilities, medical care etc and never have to resort to a credit card to buy which they then struggle to pay.

Speaking as a refired labor lawyer, our clients who were most enamoured with the idea of credit checks to screen employees were the very ones who paid lousy wages and whose workers would end up with a bad credit report because they couldn't pay their bills on what they made no matter how hard they worked.

No one should be penalized for a medical bankruptcy.  Anyone can have the bad luck of being diagnosed with a stage 3 cancer, as a friend of mine was. Though she was personally paying $600/month in health insurance, the copays and deductibles were insanely high, and she was forced to declare bankruptcy.  She applied for a job with a stellar resume and a squeaky clean record (not to mention her sense of responsibility in having health insurance).  The company turned her down only because of her bankruptcy.  When she explained to them that she had a choice between death and bankruptcy, they were totally dispassionate.  When she told me her story I was floored, but ironically not surprised given these Dickensian times.
Credit checks constitute job discrimination against the poor.  Who of decent character could be in favor of that?

There is a huge difference between people who have limited funds and pay their bills..(or have to jungle bills to attempt to pay everyone, thus resulting in late payments etc) and those that have money and don't pay their bills.
